Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Secure, Robust, and Resilient AI-enabled System Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has gained significant attention in recent years as an enabler of technologies such as autonomous cyber-physical systems and cybersecurity. This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth with a focus on secure, robust, and resilient AI-enabled system engineering. In each summer, ten undergraduate students will participate in research for ten weeks. During the research, participants will learn engineering principles to support the rigorous design and quantitative test of systems and incorporate AI components to ensure properties such as security, robustness, and resilience. This program will provide a research experience with a balance of theory, hands-on practical skills, and applications. The project is led by a team of experienced faculty who will mentor the participating researchers through a number of professional development activities, which prepare them to take a systems perspective while maintaining technical excellence to enhance the robustness of AI-enabled systems in commercial and societal contexts. This project will provide unique opportunities for undergraduate students, especially for those from underrepresented and minority groups and institutions with limited research resources, to participate in real-world research.

Artificial intelligence has gained significant attention in recent years as an enabler of technologies such as autonomous cyber physical systems and cyber security. However, engineering principles to support the rigorous design and quantitative test of systems incorporating AI components are needed to ensure properties such as security, robustness, and resilience. AI system engineering research will provide the foundation required to establish user trust and promote regulatory activities such as safety assurance. To enable to the promise of AI systems, this project proposes a unique Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site focused on secure, robust, and resilient AI-enabled system engineering. This REU Site will intertwine AI research with cybersecurity and systems engineering in a portfolio of synergistic projects. Ten undergraduate students will be engaged in a ten-week summer research program to conduct research at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth (UMD). The themes of the proposed REU Site are AI, cybersecurity, and system engineering research and their combined implications. Specifically, the following research topics will be explored: (1) cyber attacks that degrade the performance of AI algorithms; (2) AI-enabled cybersecurity against malicious actors; (3) resilient AI-enabled system engineering methods. These research themes will create opportunities for multidisciplinary knowledge sharing between AI and cybersecurity from software, hardware and system engineering perspectives, including topics in biometrics, UAVs, brain computer interaction, and signal processing. The REU will prepare talented young researchers to take a systems perspective, while maintaining technical excellence to enhance the robustness of AI-enabled systems in commercial and societal contexts. The site will provide unique opportunities for undergraduate students, especially for those from underrepresented and minority groups and institutions with limited research resources, to participate in real-world research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary:

This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site focuses on secure, robust, and resilient AI-enabled system engineering. 31 undergraduate students were selected to participate in research for ten weeks at the Cybersecurity Center of the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth in 2021-2023. This program provided research experiences with a balance of theory, hands-on practical skills, and applications. During the research, participants learned engineering principles to support the rigorous design and quantitative test of systems and incorporate AI components to ensure properties such as security, robustness, and resilience.

Intellectual Merit:

Research and Publication: The resulting product of this award includes nine peer-reviewed conference and journal papers in the areas of AI, cybersecurity, robotics, signal processing, machine learning, and medical imaging. 6 out of 9 publications are REU student first-author research papers. Among these publications, one was published in a top-tier robotics conference, the IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation 2022 (ICRA), and one paper received the "Best Paper Award" at the 2021 IEEE International Symposium on Technologies for Homeland Security (HST).

Program Effects: The REU program collects self-report pre- and post-surveys each year from all participants, using a 5-point Likert scale. The overall average ratings of the pre- and post-surveys obtained in the summers of 2021, 2022, and 2023 suggest that this REU program successfully improved its participants' knowledge, skills, and experience in many aspects of research. In particular, the participants had a significant increase (i.e., minimal difference is 1.0 or more and post-survey rating is 4.0 or above) in public speaking, technical writing, research ethics, research process, and project management. The overall average rating has increased substantially from 2.8 (leaning toward Satisfactory) prior to the program to 4.0 (Fair Amount) after the program.

Career Impact: While 14 REU participants (45%) reported no prior research experiences in their pre-survey, the post-survey showed participants' appreciation of research. In particular, REU participants highly valued the role of research in their future careers and believed that this research experience enhanced their career opportunities. As of today, 19 out of 31 REU participants have completed their undergraduate degrees. 9 of these graduates started or will start their graduate study in the Master's program, and 2 have already started their PhD study. The other graduates are currently pursuing careers in the defense industry, US Navy, health informatics, IT technology, etc. 

Professional Development:

The REU PIs and mentors worked as a team to develop the research lectures, lab materials, and hands-on activities and worked closely with graduate mentors. The program was running fully online in 2021 and back to hybrid mode in 2022 and 2023. The REU participants were highly satisfied with their mentors and mentoring experience, based on four average ratings for mentoring satisfaction reported in the post-survey (4.8/5.0, 4.8/5.0, 4.6/5.0, 4.7/5.0). This professional development also prepares faculty mentors for their grant applications. They have received several prestigious NSF grants since 2021, including an NSF CAREER and a CyberCorps Scholarship for Service (SFS) award.

11 graduate students in science and engineering voluntarily joined the REU site in the summers of 2021-2023. They were trained on how to advise undergraduate students for research and gained the experience of leading a small group of students for research. The training also helped graduate students establish capabilities for their careers in academia. One graduate mentor (PhD graduate) is currently a tenure-track Assistant Professor of cybersecurity at a public university.

All REU participants completed lectures on research methods for science and engineering. Topics included research paper reading, literature search, visualization and presentation, and technical writing. In addition, the weekly meeting and midterm and final presentations allowed REU students to develop their research skills. Finally, the lecture on graduate school preparation offered detailed information and expectations of graduate study and positively impacted students' careers. 

Broader Impacts:

The 2021-2023 REU program selected 31 students out of 350 applicants with an acceptance rate of <10%. Among these applicants, 126 students are female (36%), 52 are Hispanic/Latino (15%), 43 are Black/African American (12%), and 53 are first-generation college students (15%). Among the 31 REU participants, 11 students are female (35%), 4 are Hispanic/Latino (13%), 5 are Black/African American (16%), and 6 are first-generation college students (19%). The percentages are consistent across the applicants and participants for 2021-2023, with a slight increase in Black/African American and first-generation college students from REU participants. The participants have diverse backgrounds and majors, including computer science and engineering, data science, electrical engineering, mathematics, physics, etc. Yet, they showed high self-confidence (4.4/5.0) in dealing with various challenges in study or research, particularly in cybersecurity, AI, and system engineering based on the post-survey.
